Accordingly, claimant informed respondent that this

Accordingly, this was considered a change order and
our counter expert calculated the standby according to
a half-day was wasted, and Mr Tonkin, respondent expert,

Now we will move to our claims for the standby and

colleague Mohamed Samy.

premise that this demobilisation was a breach of the
subcontract.  Therefore, this counterclaim is actually
mirroring claimant's claim.
Claimant's position is that of course it did not
commit any material breaches of the subcontract.  Its
demobilisation of the personnel of DSV-1 and
termination, both of them were rightful and fully
legitimate, and we elaborated on this in the hearing and
in various submissions.
Also, claimant established that the non-mobilisation
of the new crew was due to the delay by respondent in
obtaining approvals and also, after that, the Covid-19.
Therefore, claimant maintains that respondent's
counterclaims based on the claimant's alleged
demobilisation must fail.
Now to the details of the counterclaim.
So here, under this head of counterclaim, respondent
made four claims.  The first one is the alleged
additional standby cost of vessels allegedly chartered
by respondent to carry out the works in tandem with that
of claimant.
The second is alleged additional port logistics,
logistical cost.
The third is additional cost related to scaffolding
provided to MOP.
The fourth is additional cost related to
pre-commissioning equipment and storage.
Before I turn into the details of these claims,
I would like to respond to a point that was made by
respondent just now in the presentation.
Respondent says that there was evidence submitted in
the witness statement by respondent and this evidence
was not countered by claimant.  Here I have two
comments.
The first one is that it is actually up to
respondent to prove its case; it's not up to claimant to
provide evidence that are countering or that are proving
that, for example, the tugs and barges were used for
other purposes.  It's not for us to prove this.  It is

Also, respondent says: we have provided factual
evidence in the witness statements that prove that these

works, and you -- which is claimant -- did not provide
any evidence to prove that it was hired for other

Actually, it was impossible for claimant to do this,

So it's not up to us to prove this.  It is up to
respondents.
What respondent mentioned here as evidence was only
the witness statement by Mr Tang.
Nothing was provided in terms of documents.  Nothing
was provided in terms of documents showing that these

Nothing was provided to prove that they were used

For example, the 36-inch pipeline, which should be laid

So this is a preliminary point I wanted to start
with, and now to the details of each element of the

The first one is the alleged standby costs of the

So respondent's allegation here is that under the

Respondent alleged that by the time of the

Respondent then alleged that as a result of the

Therefore, respondent is claiming that the standby

These barge and tugs stayed on standby doing

This is respondent's claim.
As I said, respondent has submitted no evidence that
this long time is attributable to claimant; not
respondent's failure to resume the work or to appoint

Actually, the delay experts have concluded that the
36-inch pipeline was not completed by COOEC by the date

Also, this is very important.  It's worth mentioning

According to DISA -- so this is a letter from DISA
to respondent dated 19 January 2021.  If we can go to
page 6.  Down, please, a bit.
So it states here that:
"Subcontractor terminated in full its Agreement for
DSV Subsea Work ..."
Which is our subcontract.
And then (ii):
"Subcontractor [which is here COOEC] confirmed that
neither Subcontractor nor MOP would be proceeding with
the execution of the DSV Subsea Work."
So this is by DISA, stating that COOEC confirmed
that COOEC itself would not proceed with the execution
of the DSV subsea work:
"(iii) Subcontractor had no replacement
Sub-Subcontractor(s) to complete the DSV Subsea Work.
"(iv) Subcontractor [which is COOEC again] had no
intention to hire a replacement Sub-Subcontractor to
execute Subcontractor's Subsea DSV Work."
So here we are in front of a full abandonment by
COOEC of its work before DISA.
DISA had to wait for whatever time, we don't know,
until DISA completed the work.  So it was COOEC
completely stopping the works, not doing any work for
maybe a year, or we don't know the exact period, and
then COOEC wants to put the responsibility of this full

So this cannot go that way, of course.
Furthermore, claimant here notes also that
respondent did not provide any evidence whatsoever to
support any aspect of this claim during its written
submission.  We have seen actually evidence for the
first time in the expert report of Mr Michael Tonkin,
including contracts, invoices, proof of payment and so
on, but we didn't have any evidence of any sort
concerning this claim in the written submissions of
respondent.
Even in the evidence submitted by Mr Tonkin,
respondent also failed to provide any evidence that the
barges and tugs in question were used for the purpose of
claimant's scope of work and were committed to claimant.
Nothing at all, except for mere allegations by
respondent.  Just allegations.
As indicated in claimant's submissions, claimant's
scope was in parallel with respondent's scope.
Actually, the whole project was not assigned to
claimant; it was only part of the scope of work.
Accordingly, the mere hiring of barges and tugs does
not automatically prove that they were dedicated to
claimant's works.  Respondent had to do the extra work
of proving that these barges and tugs were to be used by
claimant exclusively.  This was up to respondent to
prove, not up to claimant to disprove.
For example, one of the exhibits relied by Mr Tonkin
is the subcontract between respondent and Posh Saudi
Company for the barge Maritime Diamond and tug Posh
Panglima.  It is MT-11.3.1.  If we can open F462,
please.
If you can go to the next page.  So the first line:
"This SUBCONTRACT is made and entered into,
effective on 23rd of Oct. 2018 ..."
This is actually a full year before even the
subcontract, our subcontract was concluded -- a full
year before our subcontract.
Furthermore, this contract stated that the

Therefore, it's clear that this barge and tug

because it was much -- way before claimant was even

Therefore, any claims related to these barges, this

Second, a large number of the invoices used by

Britoil 23, so if you can have, for example, F465,
page 16.  Just by way of example.
This is an invoice for a barge called Britoil.  For
example, demobilisation fee.  If you go down, annex A,
table 2.3 -- above, above.  Yes.
So this here addresses Britoil 58, Britoil 59,
Britoil 23.  We do not know anything about these barges.
Respondent never made claims about them.
This is for the barge Maritime Diamond and its tug
Posh Panglima.
Regarding the other one, the other combination,
which is barge Miclyn -- I don't know the
pronunciation -- Miclyn 258 and tug Zakher Commander.
Mr Tonkin only provided charterparties for them.  Again,
nothing in these charterparties make any reference to
claimant's scope of work or state that the barge would
be used for the performance of its scope of work.
If we can open F463.  This is the charterparty of
Miclyn 259.  If we can go down the page, the last line,
I think.  So the last line says:
"... Barge to be utilised on the Berri Pipeline
Replacement Project ..."
Just that.  No specification at all of which part of
this project the barge would be used, which scope of
work.  And we now know that claimant does not have the

Also, claimant claims costs and charges for berth of
its barge and release of its tugs on 15 September to
11 March.
Respondent here alleged that regarding tug Posh
Panglima and barge Maritime Diamond, the tug was only
released on 15 September and the barge continued on
standby until 11 March.
However, claimant's demobilisation took place way
before those dates.  It was on 5 March.
Actually, respondent here is claiming for damages.
For a claim for damages to be acceptable under Saudi
law, there must be a causal link between the alleged
fault, which is here the demobilisation, and the alleged
damage claimed under the claim.
This long period of alleged standby demonstrates the
absence of this causal link between the demobilisation
and the standby costs.
Respondent actually did not provide any documents
that evidenced that these barges and tugs were in total
standby as respondent alleges.
The mere hiring of these barges and tugs does not
necessarily entail that they were in standby, because as
I said, there were other parts of the work that may have
used these barges and tugs.  Again, we do not know these
are the barges and tugs of respondent.  We do not know
what they were used for.  It is up to respondent to
prove, not up to claimant to disprove.
Actually, respondent did not submit the DPRs of any
of these barges.  It could have provided these DPRs
showing the standby, showing the work, showing whatever
that vessel or the barge was doing.
Also, even if they were in standby, regarding
Maritime Diamond and Posh Panglima, respondent alleged
that it was in standby for more than a year, as I said,
from 5 March 2020 to 11 March 2021.
This extremely long period, a full year of standby,
is totally unreasonable and should be attributed fully
to respondent.  This especially in light of what I said
before, that DISA itself said that it was a decision by
respondent not to do the works.
So I don't know how respondent has decided to stop
everything, not to do the work itself, not to assign any
subcontractor to do the work, and then requires claimant
to pay for its decision to stop the work for a full
year.
This does not work that way.
Respondent has a duty to mitigate any losses it
might suffer according to Saudi law, Article 137 of the
Saudi Civil Code.  This was addressed in our
submissions.
Respondent didn't have actually to retain the
combination on standby for this very long period of
time.  They must have been demobilised once the work
stopped, in order to save the alleged cost and mitigate
the damage.
Respondent didn't do that and kept this combination
in standby for this long period, although it has decided
to stop the work and not to assign a replacement
subcontractor.
Therefore, respondent shall bear the consequences of
its violation of the duty to mitigate.
Here, respondent's witness alleged that the
respondent has conducted an assessment of the available
option and found that this option of keeping the vessel
in standby was less costly than demobilising them and
remobilising again.
This was in Mr Tang's witness statement, page 31,
paragraph 202.
However, apart from the fact of course that the
decision to stop the work and not to assign
a replacement subcontract was a decision by respondent,
respondent and also Mr Tang did not present any evidence
of this assessment.
So Mr Tang is saying that: we have made an
assessment of the cost and benefit of two options and
found that the option that we adopted is the less costly
option.
However, no evidence at all was presented for this
assessment.  No evidence showing, for example, what
would be the cost if respondent has chosen to demobilise
the vessels; what would be the cost if respondent had
decided to keep them on standby, and a comparison that
was made between the two options.  Nothing at all.  Just
respondent's words.
Similarly, respondent alleged that in order to
mitigate its costs, respondent decided to berth the
barge at an appropriate port to release the tugs.  So
respondent said that this was a mitigation
thing: instead of keeping the tug, the barge could be
berthed in a port and the tug released.
However, respondent didn't do that until on
15 September, more than six months after the alleged
demobilisation.  This period is of course unjustifiable.
It has actually caused around $1 million of standby for
the tug Posh Panglima.
Respondent didn't even try to explain or justify why
it maintained the barge for this long time, except
actually for Mr Tang just saying that: we took some time
looking for an agent and some time trying to berth and
some time trying to look for a port.
No evidence, no substantiation, nothing at all.
Regarding the other combination of Miclyn 259 and
tug Zakher Commander, respondent here invoked a minimum
charter period for this combination.
However, this doesn't help respondent as well.
According to the charterparty cited by Mr Tonkin,
respondent chartered the combination on 17 January.
The same document that is open now, if we can go
a bit up, so number 2, at the top of the page, "Place
and Date", so the date is 17 January.
As said by respondent, the minimum charter period
was four months, so this ends on 17 May 2020 and not
9 June: a difference of about a month.
In all cases, the subcontract performance should
have been completed on 30 April.  Therefore, claimant
should not be responsible for chartering the combination
for a longer period.  So according to the subcontract,
it should have been terminated normally or finished on
30 April.  So claimant should not be responsible for the
period beyond that.
Further -- and this is more important -- the
chartering, because respondent here is mentioning that
this is a minimum period, therefore the price would have
been paid by respondent in all cases regardless of
whether a demobilisation has taken place or not.
Third, in any event, for both of the combination,
the standby costs after the subcontract termination on
1 May should be at respondent's expense, not claimant's.
Why is that?  Because according to clause 1.2 of
schedule G of the subcontract, which respondent actually
invoked, the free issue material should be furnished to
claimant by respondent upon claimant's request when
claimant request.
Respondent argues that the barges could not be
released because they contain material and equipment
required for the continuation of the abandoned work.
However, this is unplausible because respondent --
because there were no works that were to be done at that
time actually.  Claimant further explained in its SOR
that the free issue materials were to be furnished upon
request.
Accordingly, when claimant terminated, actually
there was no request.  Therefore, there was no need for
keeping this free issue material, especially again, and
I repeat it, as respondent decided not to hire another
subcontractor and decided not to perform the work
itself.
Finally, this claim is not compensible under Saudi
law for being unforeseeable.  So according to
Article 180 of the Saudi Civil Code, damage in
contractual liability must be foreseeable.  This is one
of the differences between contractual liability and
tortious liability.  Here we are in contractual
liability.  So a damage that is compensible must be
foreseeable at the time of the contract conclusion.
Of course, claimant did not expect at the time of
entering into the subcontract, that if it demobilises
the crew of DSV-1, this would lead to a standby of the
barge for a period reaching one year after that.  This
was totally unexpected and unforeseeable by claimant at
the time of concluding the contract.
Then the second counterclaim, or the second element
of the first counterclaim regarding additional
logistical costs.  Again, what I mentioned regarding the
first claim can also be said here.  The claim concerns
cost regarding combinations of barges and tugs and
I have established that respondent is not entitled to
any amounts regarding these barges and tugs, because
they were not attributable to claimant.  The same
applies here for the same reasons.  None of the evidence
submitted by respondent provide any support for the
allegation that these costs were incurred in relation to
the works of claimant, or that the barges and tugs in
question were related to claimant's work by any means.
Further, actually, the duration of the contract that
was submitted by respondent as an evidence, it was R56,
was a full year from June 2020 to June 2021.  This
period does not correspond with the period that was
actually specified for the performance of the works
according to the subcontract, which was only
five months.
This shows actually that these barges and tugs were
not to be used for claimant's scope.
Also, Dr Al Mansoury notes unexplained multiple port
agency fees on invoices for barge KST 3308 and
Maritime Diamond under voucher 1.
Then I move now to the third element of the claim
regarding scaffolding.  Respondent here alleged that
although claimant was the party responsible for
providing scaffolding for riser demolition and
installation works under the subcontract, respondent
allowed claimant to use the scaffolding already in place
provided by respondent's subcontractor; it's called
Veza Gulf(?).
Respondent also alleged that when claimant
demobilised before completing the riser installation
works, respondent had to extend the scaffolding rental
with a monthly rental cost of about 33,000 Saudi riyals.
Respondent also alleged that it would therefore be
entitled to recover this rental and hire purchase cost
for the scaffolding in order to enable the performance
of the remaining work, whether by claimant or by
a replacement contractor.
Respondent also alleged that to avoid further
extended rental cost, it hire-purchased the scaffolding
for around 138,000 Saudi riyals, which is less than --
according to respondent of course -- the equivalent of
four months' rental.
This claim is clearly on its face unreasonable and
shall be rejected for the following reasons.
First, respondent provided the contract in R43
regarding the scaffolding, and it doesn't prove at all
that it has anything to do with claimant's works.
Second, and this is important, respondent didn't
establish why claimant has to bear this cost of
scaffolding beyond demobilisation, which respondent
chose to keep hiring after this demobilisation took
place.
As we explained, after the termination, the
resumption of work was not envisaged, because respondent
itself said that to DISA.
Respondent thus should have simply dismantled this
scaffolding and terminated the contract with the
scaffolding hirer and thus avoided further cost.  This
was clearly unneeded costs.  This is especially since
the alleged contract, which is in R43, submitted by
respondent, states it shall be terminated upon a notice
by respondent.  So this was possible for respondent.
Also, after all, these costs are actually the
responsibility of the new subcontractor that would
replace claimant.  So now we say that DISA explained
clearly that respondent did not have an intention to
hire a replacement subcontractor.  But let us assume
that respondent would do that.  In this case,
scaffolding would be the responsibility of the new
subcontractor, just as it was for claimant.
Therefore, when claimant demobilised the crew,
respondent was not compelled by any means to keep the
scaffolding, because when the work resumes, the
scaffolding would be the responsibility of the other
subcontractor.
Fourth, what respondent alleges as mitigation, which
is the hire purchase, is in fact nothing but unnecessary
costs.  Respondent chose -- this was a choice -- to
spend the cost of the hire purchase for the benefit of
its overall activities, because it's not clear whether
it would be used for claimant scope or other scope, and
for other projects.  Respondent made no clue to the
basis to request claimant to pay for this purchase of
the scaffolding.
Finally, again, this alleged damage is not
compensible under Saudi law for being unforeseeable.
The foreseeable, what was foreseeable for claimant
when it concluded the subcontract, or for any other
subcontractor, it was that if claimant chose to
demobilise the vessel and if respondent hires another
subcontractor, a replacement subcontractor, it would be
up to this replacement subcontractor to bear the cost of
scaffolding, not for respondent.
Therefore, claimant was not expecting respondent to
keep the scaffolding for any reason.
Finally, regarding the fourth element of this claim
or counterclaim, which is additional cost related to
pre-commissioning equipment storage and concrete
mattresses, respondent here is alleging that, as
a consequence of claimant's wrongful suspension and
termination, this equipment and material required to be
stored for an extended period until a replacement
subcontractor was appointed.
This period, of course, according to respondent,
required additional costs.
Respondent here claimed two parts of storage costs:
the FCG equipment, which was rented according to
respondent from 5 March 2020 to 1 July 2021, and the
concrete mattresses, which was rented from 5 March 2020
to 23 January 2021.
Respondent alleged that such costs are incurred,
such that the FCG equipment and the concrete mattresses
could be used in the completion of the terminated works.
However, claimant should not be liable for the
storage cost after the demobilisation, in particular for
a very long period of time that exceeded 10 months since
demobilisation.  This is the same unreasonableness that
was explained regarding all the above counterclaims,
especially, again, as respondent has decided not to
continue the works, decided not to hire other
subcontractors.
Actually, respondent did not submit any explanation
for the alleged long period of storage that reached
1.5 years after termination.
Second, this cost of storage shall not be borne by
claimant, as the demobilisation was not the cause of
these costs alleged by respondent.  Actually, the actual
cause of these alleged costs was that respondent has
prematurely procured the alleged material and equipment.
As mentioned by respondent itself, this material and
equipment were to be used for pre-commissioning, which
is after all the works have been completed.
Respondent never notified or invoiced claimant of
its procurement of any of this equipment.  So it was
a fully voluntary decision by respondent to prematurely
get this material and equipment before it was needed by
claimant.
Of course, that respondent has procured this
material and equipment long before the pre-commissioning
is a decision taken by respondent.  Claimant has nothing
to do with it and therefore, claimant shall not bear its
consequences.
In other words, the alleged demobilisation was not
the effective cause.  Claimant's demobilisation was not
the effective cause of this damage.  Again, according to
Saudi law, compensation cannot be awarded unless the
alleged breach is the effective cause of the alleged
damage.  This is based on Article 120 of the Saudi Civil
Code, which provides that every fault that causes damage
to another party makes the perpetrator liable to
damages.  Therefore, the fault must be causing the
damage.  This is not the case here.
Finally, as we stated regarding all other elements,
this element is not compensible for being unforeseeable.
It was not expected of course by claimant at the time of
subcontract that respondent would prematurely provide
this equipment without any imminent need, and it was of
course not expected that this material would have to be
waiting for about 1.5 years until they are being used
again, only because respondent has decided not to
continue the works and not to assign any other
subcontractors.
Here I conclude the first counterclaim and give the
floor to my colleague Mohamed Sallam to continue the
other ones.
Opening submissions on counterclaim by MR SALLAM
ALLAM:So I'll be talking now about the remaining
counterclaims, starting with the first allegation
regarding LOI welders costs.  This under D2.
The LOI are mainly part of obtaining work permits
that fall within the liability of claimant and this is
undisputed between the parties.  Accordingly, the normal
flow of business was that claimant is to proceed with
the obtaining the LOI.  However, this was not the case,
and we elaborated on this part in our submission and
showed that COOEC practically forced this service upon
Maridive and proceeded without confirmation.
So in other words, MOP did not agree to the rates of
these services backcharged by COOEC.
Claimant rejected the respondent invoice because it
was 15 times more than the actual cost that it took to
issue the work permits for the 12 welders.
Claimant required some clarification and breakdown
from respondent.  Respondent abstained from providing
the invoice, although it received the invoice from its
subcontractor in December 2019, but it didn't provide it
to claimant when it requested.
This invoice is under R44 and claimant submitted
under C245 that the actual cost for the welder is way
cheaper than what respondent charged claimant.  In this
regard, Dr Al Mansoury calculated this counterclaim on
the second option based on claimant's calculation and
claimant's exhibit C245, which provide that the cost of
this service is only US$1,200 and 345 per welder.
The second item of this invoice is the 15 per cent
mark-up applied by COOEC and in this regard, both
quantum experts, according to them, they have not found
any contractual support for the 15 per cent mark-up
applied by COOEC.  That's why claimant respectfully
request the tribunal to dismiss all amounts of
15 per cent mark-up as added by respondent invoiced in
its invoices without any contractual basis.
The next counterclaim is provision of port captain
for out-of-Kingdom inspection for DSV-1, and in this
counterclaim both experts agreed that they are unable to
provide assessment to this counterclaim due to absence
of any breakdown.
Accordingly, we will not elaborate on this
counterclaim.
The next counterclaim under D3 is COOEC claims
relating to cost of welding and coating consumables.
Respondent submitted invoice for welding and coating
consumables that it has allegedly incurred during the
course of the subcontract, but the evidence submitted by
respondent lacks any purchase order that prove that such
purchase is based on claimant's request, and it has
failed also to deliver any invoice to claimants
according to the subcontract.
Mr Tonkin, respondent's expert, considered that
there would be the cost associated with these materials,
notwithstanding that he has not been able to verify the
actual cost.  And Dr Al Mansoury also concluded that
there was no substantiation of the incurred costs
provided to him in the document in order to verify or
confirm the amount claimed for the welding and coating
consumable and be satisfied that there were actual costs
incurred by COOEC.
Then we have the counterclaim of failure to
safeguard project material.  In this counterclaim,
respondent is claiming cost for rectifying the riser
clamps, as they should have preserved a certain level of
nitrogen, which respondent allege that claimant did not
maintain this nitrogen level.
They claim costs they incurred to preserve these
risers and clamps for their installation when completing
the terminated work.
However, this counterclaim lacks any merit, for the
following reasons.
First, respondent never submitted any evidence that
those risers clamps relating to claimant scope of work.
Even the invoices submitted under R59, R60, R111 does
not evidence that they are related to claimant's scope
of work during the performance.
It might be relating to other activity, because we
mentioned that COOEC also had a parallel scope and it
also used risers and guards, so it has to prove that
these risers and guards relate to claimant's scope of
work, which it clearly failed to.
Second, respondent submitted in these exhibits
invoices for a mere refilling of nitrogen gas.
Respondent has never evidenced that this nitrogen gas
was injected in these riser clamps relating to
claimant's work.
There was also a discrepancy in the submission of
COOEC's where they claim that they made the maintenance
orders for these riser clamps in July and November 2021.
However, the expert showed that the invoices are in July
and November 2020.  But in both cases, whether the
maintenance was made in 20 July and -- August
and November 2020 or in 2021, in both cases this is
a very long time after claimant's demobilisation and
termination.
Claimant terminated on 1 May and respondent
terminated also on 21 May.  So if these risers were
defective when they were on claimant's position,
respondent would have made their maintenance immediately
after receiving them in May 2020, not after three months
and then after six months doing this maintenance.
It would have rectified them all at one time, like
if all these risers are defective from claimants,
respondent would have simply made all maintenance for
them in one time, not one in August and then another
maintenance in November.
This proves that this defection has nothing to do
with claimants, who left this equipment since May 2020.
Respondent didn't prove any incidence of decrease of
the nitrogen level during the performance of the
subcontract.  On the contrary, we proved during our
submissions in the statement of rejoinder,
paragraph 119, that all nitrogen level was preserved
during the performance of the subcontract.  Accordingly,
the only logical explanation: that these nitrogen levels
were decreased after the termination, after claimant
left the works.
In this regard, claimant has no obligation at all to
preserve the equipment after its termination and
accordingly, respondent in this regard relies on
clause 1.3 of schedule G, which relates to preserving
the material during the performance of the work, but
normally this clause is relating to preserving the
material during the performance of the work, not after
termination of the work.
Actually, clause 25.4 of schedule A stipulates that
subcontractor shall stop performance of the terminated
work effective on the day of termination.  So after
termination claim, had no obligation at all to preserve
these materials or any other materials.
With regards also to the 15 per cent mark-up applied
by claimant, both experts did not find any contractual
